Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Hybrid Modeling of Reactive Transport in Porous and Fractured Media
Award.AbstractNarration:
Subsurface flow and transport take place in complex heterogeneous environments that exhibit a hierarchy of scales. More often than not, physical and bio-geochemical phenomena on one scale (e.g., a pore scale) affect, and are coupled to phenomena on a vastly different scale (e.g., a field scale). Such phenomena defy coarse-scale continuum descriptions, since they exhibit high localization (e.g., propagation of reactive fronts and biofilm growth) and/or strong nonlinear coupling between the processes involved (e.g., dynamic changes in porosity and permeability due to dissolution or precipitation). Hybrid numerical algorithms are to be used when coarse-scale continuum models fail to accurately describe a physical phenomenon in a small part of a computational domain. Accurate and efficient coupling of two (or more) models operating on vastly different spatial and/or temporal scales in a hybrid remains a major theoretical and computational challenge. A key to the success of a hybrid method is an efficient implementation of coupling conditions on the interface between its constitutive models. Additionally, uncertainty about pore geometry undermines the veracity of pore-scale simulations and, hence, of hybrid simulations of which they are a constitutive part. Overreaching goals of the proposed activity are to establish a theoretical foundation for hybrid modeling of subsurface flow and transport, to develop corresponding numerical algorithms, and to provide computational tools for robust uncertainty quantification in hybrid models. To achieve these goals, the investigators will develop hybrid algorithms for reactive flows in fractured and porous media, quantify uncertainty in pore-scale geometry in hybrid simulations, and experimentally validate hybrid simulations.

In terms of broader impact, this proposal will enhance sustainability of essential water resources. Groundwater is a principal source of domestic water supply in the United States, and it is a major source of fresh water for industrial, agricultural and public uses. By establishing a novel modeling framework, this proposal will provide a scientific basis for reliable predictions of impacts of land use change and climate change, and more accurate assessments of groundwater contamination risks. The methods and algorithms developed in the course of the proposed activity will lay a solid foundation for improved quantitative understanding of subsurface processes with tightly coupled pore- and field-scales. The proposal will support the efforts of graduate students. The investigators will actively promote STEM career paths of underrepresented groups, and establish an outreach K-12 program dedicated to providing an intensive college prep education for motivated low-income students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Current modeling approaches to flow and transport in porous media can be subdivided into pore-scale and Darcy-scale (macroscopic) models. While pore-scale models enable one to describe micro-scale processes with a high degree of fidelity, they are impractical in modeling processes at scales larger than a small core due to both high computational costs and the lack of detailed information about the pore geometry in the whole computational domain. Macroscopic models, which treat a porous medium as an “averaged” continuum, overcome these limitations at the cost of relying on largely phenomenological descriptions, e.g., Darcy’s law for fluid flow and an advection-dispersion equation (ADE) for transport. While useful in a variety of applications, macroscopic models fail to capture experimentally observed transport features, such as long tails in breakthrough curves, and the onset of instability in variable-density flows. ADE-based models can significantly over-predict the extent of reactions in mixing-induced chemical transformations.  Scientific understanding [1,4] and  computational tools for hybrid pore-scale/continuum-scale algorithms [1,2,3,6,8,9] have been developed in this research. Hybrid models combine the physical rigor of pore-scale modeling with the computational efficiency of its continuum-scale counterpart [6,8,9]. Such algorithms/models  enable one to model phenomena where the small-scale processes significantly affect large-scale behavior [5,6,8] and defy classical macroscopic models. Importantly, it has been demonstrated that physics-based multiscale hybrid models can be predictive, i.e. the coupling error in hybrid models can be bounded by the upscaling error [6]: this represents an important advancement in achieving predictive understanding of inherently multiscale hydrological systems. Furthermore,   imaging processing techniques have successfully been combined with multiscale models parametrization to predict breakthrough curves in and permeability of rock samples from the Hanford site [7], therefore laying the foundation for data-driven multiscale models of subsurface flow and transport processes.

Broader Impacts: This research has contributed to enhance sustainability of essential water resources. Groundwater is the principal source of domestic water supply in the United States, and it is a major source of fresh water for industrial, agricultural and public uses. By establishing a novel modeling framework, this research has advanced the scientific basis needed for reliable predictions of contaminant transport in the subsurface  and more accurate assessments of risks to water quality posed by contamination. The methods and algorithms developed in the course of the proposed activity have laid a solid foundation for improved quantitative understanding of subsurface processes with tightly coupled pore- and field-scales, such as fouling of closed-loop geothermal systems, hydraulic fracturing, and reduction of infiltration capacity of recharge ponds due to pore clogging. The proposal has supported the efforts of one female graduate student. Furthermore, the science and understanding developed during this research have been included in a new graduate class at Stanford University “ENERGY 289: Multiscale Methods for Transport in Porous Media”, as well as in the Third edition of the Handbook of Groundwater Engineering [4].
